entry.et: Middle English than, then then, than, from Old English thonne, thænne; akin to Old High German denne then, than, Old English thæt that

def.dt: :soon after that :next in order of time walked to the door, then turned
:following next after in order of position, narration, or enumeration :being next in a series first came the clowns, and then came the elephants
:in addition :besides then there is the interest to be paid
:in that case take it, then, if you want it so much

dt.un: used after but to qualify or offset a preceding statement she lost the race, but then she never really expected to win

def.dt: :according to that :as may be inferred your mind is made up, then
:as it appears :by way of summing up the cause of the accident, then, is established
:as a necessary consequence if the angles are equal, then the complements are equal
:with much more in addition would require all his strength and then some
:that time since then, he's been more cautious
:existing or acting at or belonging to the time mentioned the then secretary of state
:on the spot :immediately wanted the money right then and there
:from time to time :occasionally now and then we go off to the country

entry.et: Middle English everich, every, from Old English ǣfre ǣlc, from ǣfre ever + ǣlc each

def.dt: :being each individual or part of a group without exception
:being each in a series or succession every few days every once in a while
:being each within a range of possibilities was given every chance
:complete entire we have every confidence in her
